GitHub - fedidcg/FedCM: A privacy preserving federated identity Web API3/5/2022

A privacy preserving federated identity Web API. Contribute to fedidcg/FedCM development by creating an account on GitHub.

* Rename explainer to explorations.

The current explainer folder holds an exploration into the design space
that FedCM is considering. It takes about a lot of possible things that
could be done and ways to do that.

This is different from the explainer that will need to be produced which
explains the FedCM API specifically.

This PR moves the `explainer` folder to an `explorations` folder to make
room for the future explainer.

          <div data-target="readme-toc.content" class="Box-body px-5 pb-5">
            <article class="markdown-body entry-content container-lg" itemprop="text"><h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-fedid-cg-federated-credentials-management" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#fedid-cg-federated-credentials-management"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>FedID CG Federated Credentials Management</h1>
<p dir="auto">This is the repository for the W3C's FedID CG Federated Credentials Management API.</p>
<p dir="auto">Explainer: <a href="/fedidcg/FedCM/blob/main/explainer.md">explainer.md</a></p>
<p dir="auto">Work-in-progress specification: <a href="https://fedidcg.github.io/FedCM/" rel="nofollow">https://fedidcg.github.io/FedCM/</a></p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-introduction" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#introduction"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Introduction</h2>
<p dir="auto">As the web has evolved there have been ongoing privacy-oriented changes
(<a href="https://blog.chromium.org/2020/01/building-more-private-web-path-towards.html" rel="nofollow">example</a>) and underlying privacy
<a href="https://github.com/michaelkleber/privacy-model">principles</a>. With those
changes some underlying assumptions of the web are changing. One of those
changes is the deprecation of third-party cookies. While overall good for the
web, third-party cookie deprecation leaves holes in how some existing systems
on the web were designed and deployed.</p>
<p dir="auto">Federated Credentials Management API aims to fill the specific hole left by
the removal of third-party cookies on federated login. Historically this has
relied on third-party cookies or navigational redirects in order to function
as they were the primitives provided by the web.</p>
<p dir="auto">The <a href="/fedidcg/FedCM/blob/main/explainer.md">explainer</a> and <a href="https://fedidcg.github.io/FedCM" rel="nofollow">spec</a>
provide a potential API and the rational behind how that API was designed.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-contributing" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#contributing"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Contributing</h2>
<p dir="auto">Much of the FedCM specification has evolved due to the experimentation detailed
in the <a href="/fedidcg/FedCM/blob/main/explorations/README.md">explorations</a>. The explorations documents give a good
overview of the <em>why</em> of the FedCM API. Please read over the documents to
understand how the current API has evolved.</p>
<p dir="auto">There are several ways to contribute to the Federated Credential Management API.</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>
<p dir="auto">If you're an interested party and have potential requirements, they can be
submitted to the <a href="https://github.com/IDBrowserUseCases/docs">IDBrowserUseCases</a>
repository. There are also discussions ongoing in the
<a href="https://www.w3.org/community/fed-id/" rel="nofollow">Fed-ID CG</a> about the various use cases.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">If you'd like to try out the current demo of the FedCM API you can follow the
<a href="/fedidcg/FedCM/blob/main/explorations/HOWTO.md">HOWTO</a> document.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">If you're an Identity Provider, there are two sides of the implementation that
will be needed and any feedback on either side is appreciated.</p>
<ol dir="auto">
<li>The <a href="https://fedidcg.github.io/FedCM/#idp-api" rel="nofollow">Identity Provider API</a> describes
the manifest and API needed server side.</li>
<li>The <a href="https://fedidcg.github.io/FedCM/#browser-api" rel="nofollow">Browser API</a> describes the JavaScript
interface to FedCM which will need to be utilized.</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p dir="auto">If you're a Relying Party (i.e. website) and would like to test the changes out
we'd appreciate feedback, you'll need to do something similar to the
<a href="/fedidcg/FedCM/blob/main/explorations/HOWTO.md">HOWTO.md</a> to setup a fake IDP which can serve the needed
JavaScript. (Until an IDP provides first party JavaScript to work with FedCM
this integration will be tricker). You can also review the demo provided by the
HOWTO and take a look at the
<a href="https://fedidcg.github.io/FedCM/#rp-api" rel="nofollow">Relying Party API</a> to see what is needed
on the RP side.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-code-of-conduct" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#code-of-conduct"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Code of Conduct</h2>
<p dir="auto">This group operates under <a href="http://www.w3.org/Consortium/cepc/" rel="nofollow">W3C's Code of Conduct Policy</a>.</p>
</article>

readabilityObject.title: GitHub - fedidcg/FedCM: A privacy preserving federated identity Web API
readabilityObject.content:
FedID CG Federated Credentials Management

This is the repository for the W3C's FedID CG Federated Credentials Management API.

Explainer: explainer.md

Work-in-progress specification: https://fedidcg.github.io/FedCM/

Introduction

As the web has evolved there have been ongoing privacy-oriented changes (example) and underlying privacy principles. With those changes some underlying assumptions of the web are changing. One of those changes is the deprecation of third-party cookies. While overall good for the web, third-party cookie deprecation leaves holes in how some existing systems on the web were designed and deployed.

Federated Credentials Management API aims to fill the specific hole left by the removal of third-party cookies on federated login. Historically this has relied on third-party cookies or navigational redirects in order to function as they were the primitives provided by the web.

The explainer and spec provide a potential API and the rational behind how that API was designed.

Contributing

Much of the FedCM specification has evolved due to the experimentation detailed in the explorations. The explorations documents give a good overview of the why of the FedCM API. Please read over the documents to understand how the current API has evolved.

There are several ways to contribute to the Federated Credential Management API.

  • If you're an interested party and have potential requirements, they can be submitted to the IDBrowserUseCases repository. There are also discussions ongoing in the Fed-ID CG about the various use cases.

  • If you'd like to try out the current demo of the FedCM API you can follow the HOWTO document.

  • If you're an Identity Provider, there are two sides of the implementation that will be needed and any feedback on either side is appreciated.

    1. The Identity Provider API describes the manifest and API needed server side.
    2. The Browser API describes the JavaScript interface to FedCM which will need to be utilized.

  • If you're a Relying Party (i.e. website) and would like to test the changes out we'd appreciate feedback, you'll need to do something similar to the HOWTO.md to setup a fake IDP which can serve the needed JavaScript. (Until an IDP provides first party JavaScript to work with FedCM this integration will be tricker). You can also review the demo provided by the HOWTO and take a look at the Relying Party API to see what is needed on the RP side.

Code of Conduct

This group operates under W3C's Code of Conduct Policy.
